title: 105_s494
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and includes provisions for prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" introduces prisoner copayments for health care services, defining terms like account, Director, health care provider, health care visit, and prisoner. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines a qualified health care visit as any health care visit except specific circumstances like during intake, annual exams, emergencies, immunizations, visits initiated by prison staff, or referrals by prison officials. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" allows the Director of the Bureau of Prisons to assess and collect fees for health care services provided to prisoners, including copayments for health care visits, prescription medications, and visits resulting from injuries inflicted by other prisoners. Fees range from $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit and up to $5 for prescription medications. The Act allows the Director to collect fees from prisoners for health care services, including visits for injuries inflicted by other prisoners. Fees are collected from the prisoner receiving care or the one responsible for the injury, with payment timing and installment plans specified. Treatment cannot be refused based on financial reasons. The Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act prohibits refusal of treatment for prisoners based on financial reasons. Amounts collected by the Director are deposited in the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director must submit annual reports to Congress on amounts collected and the impact on health care visits by prisoners. The Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act mandates reporting on health care visits by prisoners. Prisoner copayments for health care services are required under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act.
